coredata.dc:description: In this work, we prepared a PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst by using PtCl6 2−/ZnTi layered-double-hydroxide (LDH) as precursor and revealed the in-situ topological process through modulating the reduction conditions. The Cs-corrected HAADF-STEM and XAFS verified the formation of PtZn alloy structure and also indicated the generated ZnTiOx coating layer exhibited the feature of low-coordination. In glycerol oxidation, the obtained catalyst possessed obvious advantages in intrinsic activity and glyceric acid selectivity compared with bare PtZn alloy and Pt catalysts. Confirmed by O2-TPD and XPS analysis, the alloy effect with Zn and abundant oxygen vacancies in ZnTiOx layer could enhance the glycerol oxidation activity by promoting the oxygen activation. A series of FTIR analysis revealed that the enhanced selectivity was assigned to the low-coordination ZnTiOx at the interface, optimizing the intermediate glyceraldehyde adsorption form. Additionally, an excellent reusability with 76.2 % glycerol conversion and 61.3 % glyceric acid selectivity after 5 cycles was exhibited over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this work, we prepared a PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst by using PtCl6 2−/ZnTi layered-double-hydroxide (LDH) as precursor and revealed the in-situ topological process through modulating the reduction conditions. The Cs-corrected HAADF-STEM and XAFS verified the formation of PtZn alloy structure and also indicated the generated ZnTiOx coating layer exhibited the feature of low-coordination. In glycerol oxidation, the obtained catalyst possessed obvious advantages in intrinsic activity and glyceric acid selectivity compared with bare PtZn alloy and Pt catalysts. Confirmed by O2-TPD and XPS analysis, the alloy effect with Zn and abundant oxygen vacancies in ZnTiOx layer could enhance the glycerol oxidation activity by promoting the oxygen activation. A series of FTIR analysis revealed that the enhanced selectivity was assigned to the low-coordination ZnTiOx at the interface, optimizing the intermediate glyceraldehyde adsorption form. Additionally, an excellent reusability with 76.2 % glycerol conversion and 61.3 % glyceric acid selectivity after 5 cycles was exhibited over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst.

ce:section.ce:para: The increasing demand of biodiesel generated the production of excessive glycerol byproduct, arousing a huge interest in discovering the efficient use of glycerol. The highly functional properties of glycerol make it be utilized as a chemical platform for catalytic oxidation to produce high-value-added products [1–3]. Normally, glycerol selective oxidation is confronted with the challenges referring to the transformation pathway (primary or secondary hydroxyl group) as well as the depth of oxidation (aldehyde/ketones or acids) [4,5]. Therefore, in order to realize the high yield of target product, rational design and construction of advantageous active sites that could match the continuous reaction path of glycerol oxidation matters a great deal.

It has been revealed that active metal components play crucial roles in determining the selectivity of primary/secondary hydroxyl groups in glycerol molecules. For instance, Greeley’s group using density functional theory calculations clarified that glycerol adsorbed on the Pt surface through the oxygen atom in primary hydroxy group, which is the most stable configuration with -0.46 eV binding energy [6]. Furthermore, Koper et al. found the active intermediate of initial glycerol dehydrogenation bound to the Pt surface through the primary carbon atoms [7]. Meanwhile, a large number of experimental researches have confirmed that the primary hydroxyl groups rather than the secondary primary hydroxyl groups prefer to be oxidized on Pt-based catalysts [8–11]. In conclusion, Pt-based catalysts are considered to possess unique advantage for the preferential oxidation of primary hydroxyl groups, whereas there is still a large promotion space in terms of continuous oxidation [12,13]. Generally, the method of introducing a second metal component to form alloy is deliberated to be crucial to modify the performance of monometallic metal catalysts [14,15]. Zinc, as a highly abundant, non-toxic and cheap metal element, has been drawing more attention on facilitating the catalytic performance of Pt catalysts in many reactions [16,17]. In spired by the promotional effect of PtZn alloy on activating CH bond in numerous dehydrogenation reactions, alloying Pt with Zn could also be a promising way to increase the glycerol conversion efficiency due to the rate-determining step (RDS) of COH activation in glycerol oxidation is the cleavage of CH bond [18–20]. However, Zn2+ cannot be reduced effectively by the collective reducing agents as well as the comparatively negative redox potential of Zn (Zn2+/Zn, −0.76 V versus standard hydrogen electrode) makes the preparation of PtZn alloys challenging [21]. The above difficulties can be overcome by using vaporization method or organic templating method, while could bring about other issues [22]. In case of vaporization method, the synthesis process usually takes place in a reducing atmosphere with high temperature and was difficult to control the size of particles. While in the case of the latter method, avoiding the chemisorption of species which generate in the process of synthesis (such as the solvent, anions or neutral ligands derived from metal-containing precursor solution or reducing agents) is challenging. Part of the impurities and organic compounds can be removed through heating in vacuum or inert gas, but may lead to the growth of particles. Therefore, it is of great value to propose a simple and feasible method to fabricate PtZn alloys with uniform size, high dispersion and no organic layer on the surface.

Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a class of two-dimensional (2D) layered inorganic materials, in which the metal cations are highly distributed in brucite-like layers with ordered of (M2+M3+)OH6. LDHs are effective precursors for the formation of homogeneous alloys due to the lattice confinement of the (M2+M3+)OH6 octahedral structure [23,24]. For example, Tomishige et al. obtained a well-distributed NiFe alloy catalyst using NiFeMgAl-LDHs as precursor [25]. In our previous work, we incorporated Ga3+ into the brucite-like layer of LDHs, and then introduced PdCl4 2− anion to obtain a well-dispersed PdGa alloy catalyst [26]. In this regard, the method using LDHs as precursors is a reasonable way to fabricate a highly dispersed PtZn alloy catalyst without organic layer on the surface. Moreover, another attractive feature of LDHs is inducing the low-coordination interface structure caused by the strong interaction during the structural topological transformation [27]. Wei et al. obtained a structure of low-coordination interface, derived from the NiTi-LDH precursor, which manifests as a coating layer of TiO2-x on the surface of Ni NPs [28]. In recent years, numerous studies have revealed the importance of metal-oxide interface on the catalytic performance by altering the electronic structure through charge transfer and providing a geometrical intimacy to enable a bifunctional site. It thus inspired us to make more diversified use of LDHs structural advantages to fabricate a novel catalyst with both uniform alloy and metal@MOx low-coordination interface structure, which could simultaneously promote the activation of COH and CO bonds during the process of glycerol oxidation.

To be specific, we fabricated a PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst via reduction of PtCl6 2−/ZnTi-LDHs precursors in H2 atmosphere and monitored the in-situ topological process. The Cs-corrected HAADF-STEM images and in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR) clearly confirmed the formation of PtZn alloys, while the extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) suggested the generation of low-coordination PtZn@ZnTiOx interface under the reduction of high temperature. To reveal the function of alloy and low-coordination metal@ZnTiOx interface, bare PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalyst and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst were also synthesized for comparison. Compared with monometallic Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst, the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 and PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalysts showed much higher intrinsic activity. While at similar conversion levels, the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst shows an obviously higher selectivity to glyceric acid (GLYA), which suggested that the PtZn@ZnTiOx interface structure exert a great effect on product distribution. Moreover, after cumulative use of 60 h, PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst exhibited a satisfying stability. To illuminate the synergistic effects of alloy and low-coordination interface layer, the activation behavior of oxygen and the adsorption mode of formed reaction intermediates were identified via O2-TPD, XPS and in situ FTIR experiments.

Co-precipitation method was used to prepare ZnTi-LDHs on the basis of the literature [29,30]. TiCl4 (0.79 mL), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (6.43 g) and urea (6.00 g) were dissolved in deionized water (100 mL) and violently stirred. An autoclave with 130 °C was used to age the resulting reactant for 48 h. Then the samples were dried in a vacuum freeze dryer until completely dried into powder to obtain ZnTi-LDHs precursors.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of series catalysts with PtCl6 2−/ZnTi-LDHs as precursor
ce:section.ce:para: Using the ZnTi-LDH prepared by the co-precipitation method as the precursor, we prepared series Pt-based catalysts under different reduction temperature. Concretely, 30 mL of H2PtCl6 mixed aqueous solution with concentrations of 2.56 × 10−3, 2.14 × 10−3, 1.71 × 10−3 and 0.85 × 10−3 mM were respectively prepared and 1.00 g of ZnTi-LDHs was added into the above solution. These suspensions were then heated at 80 °C for 4 h under vigorous stirring, keeping the temperature until water completely evaporating, and dried through vacuum at 60 °C for 4 h to obtain PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs precursors. Subsequently, a fussed silica reaction tube was used to load the PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs and was filled with H2/N2 (1:9) atmosphere to remove air, in which the flow is 40 mL/min. After H2/N2 flowing for 15 min., PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs were heated to 300, 500, 700 and 800 °C, respectively, and maintained these specific temperature for 3 h under H2/N2 atmosphere. Eventually, samples were cooled in H2/N2 atmosphere protection and took out when the temperature decreased to 30 °C. The obtained samples were denoted as Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300), Pt/ZnTi-MMO(500), PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ ZnTiO3(800), respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts
ce:section.ce:para: The ZnTiO3 support was prepared from ZnTi-LDHs in a reducing atmosphere at 800 °C. Subsequently, H2PtCl6 was impregnated with the same method as the above catalysts to obtain PtCl6 2-/ZnTiO3. The bimetallic PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalyst, which has the bare PtZn alloy nanoparticles without ZnTiOx interface layer, was synthesized with PtCl6 2-/ZnTiO3 as precursors heating to 700 °C at the flow rate of 40 mL/min in the H2/N2 (1:9) atmosphere, then kept the temperature for 3 h. In addition, the monometallic Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst was prepared by the same method as PtZn/ZnTiO3, while the reduction temperature maintained at 500 °C.

X–ray diffraction (XRD) (Shimadzu XRD–600) was used to identify the crystal structure of catalysts and LDHs precursor within the 2θ from 2° to 80° (scan step: 10° /min). High–resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), of which the model is JEM–2100F produced from JEOL company, was employed to characterize the catalyst morphology. JEOL ARM200F microscope was applied to obtain the Cs-corrected STEM and High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) images. Metal content was determined by a Shimadzu ICPS–7500 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP–AES). EXAFS was carried out in Institute of High Energy Physics (IHEP), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). A Thermo VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometers was used to collect the X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra, then calibrated by the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. CO pulse chemisorption and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) were performed using Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 chemisorption. A Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer was applied to record Fourier transform infrared spectra (in-situ FTIR). (For detailed preprocessing and test conditions, please refer to the Supporting Information).

The determined dispersion of Pt (D %) was obtained based on the equation:
D (%) = SF × Vad × MPt /[ms×Ws×Vm]×100,

SF is the stoichiometric factor, which is assumed to be 1:1 for CO:Pt; Vad is the volume of chemisorbed CO; X is the metal loading (∼1.5 %); MPt is the molecular weight of Pt (195.1 g mol−1); ms is the weight of sample (0.1 g); Ws is the weight fraction of Pt; and Vm is the molar volume of CO at the standard state (22.4 L). [10,30]
(For detailed preprocessing and test conditions, please refer to the Supporting Information)

According to the reaction temperature function from 70 to 85 °C (conversion less than 15 %), the oxidation kinetics of glycerol and glyceraldehyde were studied sequentially. Commonly, 5 mL of 0.3 M glycerol or 0.020 M glyceraldehyde solution and a certain amount of catalyst (glycerol/active metal molar ratio 500/1, glyceraldehyde/active metal molar ratio 200/1) were put into a glass reactor, then other procedures similar to the glycerol oxidation test described above were performed. The activation energy for glycerol and glyceraldehyde oxidation over the corresponding catalysts were calculated by using Time-Conversion diagrams at various temperatures and Arrhenius diagrams.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structure characterization of precursor and catalyst
ce:section.ce:para: The ZnTi-LDHs (Zn/Ti molar ratio: 3.0) provided through hydrothermal method was impregnated with PtCl6 2-. The obtained PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs precursor was then in situ reduced in a reduction atmosphere at 300, 500, 700 and 800 °C, respectively. The catalysts were thus denoted as Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300), Pt/ZnTi-MMO(500), PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800). The XRD pattern of the ZnTi-LDHs (Fig. S1) displays a series of diffraction peaks with the positions at 12.6 °, 24.5 °, 36.5 ° and 58.9 °, which could be assigned to (003), (006), (009) and (110) lattice planes from LDHs phase [29]. Notably, PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs precursor reduced at different temperature exhibit varying crystal structure. As shown in Fig. 1 A and B, 300 °C and 500 °C reduction temperatures resulted in the structural transformation from the ZnTi-LDHs precursor to zinc-titanium mixed metal oxides (ZnTi-MMO) [29]. A variety of diffraction peaks appear at 31.8 °, 34.4 °, 36.3 °, 47.5 °, 56.6 °, 62.9 °, and 68.0 °, which are indexed to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103) and (112) plane of ZnO phase (PDF#36-1451). Additionally, a broad diffraction peak at 25.3 ° is attributed to the (101) plane of an anatase TiO2 phase (PDF#21-1272). As the reduction temperature goes up to 700 °C, several diffraction peaks at 29.8 °, 35.1 °, 42.7 °, 53.0 °, 56.5 ° and 62.0 ° are corresponding to an Zn2TiO4 phase (PDF#25-1164) appeared. When the reduction temperature ultimately reaches 800 °C, the catalyst exhibits typical ZnTiO3 (PDF#39–0190) patterns which contain a series of reflections at 15.8 °, 24.6 °, 26.9 °, 31.0 °, 36.4 °, 44.0 °, 54.3 °, 57.8°and 63.4 °. For all cases, the XRD pattern shows no obvious reflection of metals, demonstrating that metal nanoparticles are highly dispersed and rather small in size [31,32]. By comparing the structure of the samples reducing at different temperatures, it is reasonable to speculate on the structure variation of the catalyst under reducing atmosphere conditions: the ZnTi-LDHs precursor undergo a transition from ZnTi-MMO to Zn2TiO4 phase and then to ZnTiO3 phase as the temperature increased from 300 to 800 °C.

To make the structure of alloys in PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) and PtZn/ Zn2TiO4(700) unambiguous at the nanometer-sized level, ac-HAADF-STEM images were applied, as shown in Fig. S2 and S3. In the graph of elemental mapping, the compositional distribution of Zn at the edge of the sample was exactly agreed with that of Pt, indicating the formation of PtZn alloy. In addition, Fig. 2 A show an obvious coating layer on the surface of PtZn NP over the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample, while only bare PtZn alloy without interface is observed over the PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) sample (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, EELS collected at spots a and b demonstrate that Ti L-edge and Zn K-edge signals are observed at spot a, similar to those at spot b, indicating the coverage of the ZnTiOx phase on the surface of NPs [28,30]. To further confirm the formation of alloys and the coating ZnTiOx interface layer, Pt dispersion was calculated based on CO chemisorption. Specifically, the PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) sample exhibits a much higher CO chemisorption (30.93 %) compared to that of the Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300) and Pt/ZnTi-MMO(500) samples, which is generally considered as an evidence for the isolation of Pt atoms caused by the alloy structure [35]. Additionally, an obvious decrease of CO chemisorption amount was observed over the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample, which strongly proved the existent of encapsulated interface structure on the PtZn alloy NPs but not completely covered [28,36]. While the statistical results of particle size distribution under HRTEM show that series samples had similar Pt dispersion, which is significantly different from the results of CO chemisorption. The results above verify that the obtained PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample not only have highly dispersed PtZn alloys but also form a ZnTiOx layer on their surface.

To further clarify the in situ topological process to form PtZn alloy and ZnTiOx layer interface structure, H2-TPR were performed over PtCl6 2−/ZnTi-LDHs precursor and the pristine ZnTi-LDHs. As shown in Fig. 3 A, the ZnTi-LDHs sample possesses two main hydrogen consumption peak at about 235 °C and 518 °C, which are attributed to the Ti4+ and Zn2+ cations in the layer partly reduced to their intermediate valence [37]. Notably, the TPR curve of the PtCl6 2−/ZnTi-LDHs sample shows obvious H2 consumption peaks at about 103 °C and 152 °C, which are corresponding to the reduction of bulk phase Pt species and dispersive phase Pt species, respectively [38]. Additionally, the H2 consumption peak of Zn2+ shifts toward lower temperature in PtCl6 2−/ZnTi-LDHs sample, demonstrating the reduction of Zn species was promoted by the introduction of Pt. Moreover, two small H2 consumption peaks in the range of 650–800 °C appears, attributing to the reduction of ZnTiO3 in bulk phase and the interaction between Pt species and the ZnTiO3 supports [39]. The above results of HRTEM, CO-chemisorption and TPR firmly verify the formation of alloy structure and the interface oxide layer. Moreover, the particle size of Pt-containing NPs would not change significantly when the reduction temperature increases from 300 to 800 °C, indicating the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) could efficiently inhibit the metal agglomeration.

To investigate the geometric structure of Pt in different catalysts, CO-FTIR (Fig. 3B) was employed. For all samples, numerous absorption bands within the scope of 1750–2150 cm−1 are attributed to the carbon monoxide molecule absorbed by linear adsorption on Ptterrace (near 2081 cm−1, expressed as Ptterrace CO), Ptstep/corner (near 2046 cm−1, expressed as Ptstep/corner CO), and a small quantity of Ptbridge (near 1832 cm−1, expressed as Ptbridge CO) [10,40]. With the reduction temperature increasing from 300 to 700 °C, the Ptterrace CO peak experiences a red-shift from 2081 to 2064 cm−1. Meanwhile, a similar red-shift of the Ptstep/corner CO peak is noticed, from 2046 to 2042 cm−1 for Pt/ZnTi-MMO(500) and then to 2031 cm−1 for PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) compared with that of Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300). Interestingly, in the case of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ ZnTiO3(800) sample, the spectra only shows one sharp CO peak absorbed by linear adsorption on step or corner high energy sites of Pt. The absence of CO linearly absorbed characteristic peak suggests that partial supports climbed onto the metal particles causing the formation of oxide-metal interfacial layer under the condition of high temperature reduction, and preferred to occupy the terrace Pt sites. Additionally, the overall variation of geometry structure could be reflected via the linear/bridge ratio of the adsorbed CO (RL/RB) which is calculated based on the peak areas [41]. Apparently, comparing with monometallic Pt sample formed in 300 and 500 °C, the RL/RB ratio of the PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) sample increased, indicating the isolation of continuous Pt sites by Zn atoms [42–44]. While the RL/RB ratio of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample dropped slightly compared with PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700), strongly proved the existent of the interface oxide layer [36]. The above CO-FTIR results indicate that the geometric structures of Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300) and Pt/ZnTi-MMO(500) are resemblance, while the consecutive Pt sites are isolated as the temperature increases to 700 °C, and an interface layer structure appears when the temperature reaches 800 °C.

According to the information of PtZn alloy and interface structure over PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) was measured to further confirm the change of the local atomic arrangement structure of Pt and Zn during the formation of interface layer structure. As shown in Fig. 4 , the Fourier transforms of the EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) of PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700), PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) and a series of reference samples are carried out at Pt L3-edge and Zn K-edge. Compared with Pt foil, the first nearest-coordination peak of PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) samples on the edge of Pt L3 significantly shifted towards the direction of smaller distance between atoms. To be specific, we could clearly notice that the Pt–Pt bond length is around 2.5 Å in Pt foil, while the peak at 2.3 Å in the first shell of PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) could be attributed to Pt–Zn bonds(Fig. 4A). In addition, the Zn-Zn bond coordination peaks in the Zn k-edge of the two samples move to the direction of larger distance between atoms [17,45]. Therefore, the change of atomic distance further confirms the existence of PtZn alloy in PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) samples. In the case of Zn K edge XANES spectra, the dominant peak of PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) located at ∼1.5 Å (without phase correction) could correspond to the Zn-O scattering path. As shown in Table S1, the fit analysis of PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) gives an average Zn-O distance of 1.99 ± 1.20 Å with a coordination number of 3.61, while for PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample, the Zn-O coordination distance and coordination number decrease to 1.95 ± 1.15 Å and 3.21, respectively. Notably, the coordination number of both samples are significantly smaller than that of ZnO [20,46]. According to the above results, it could indicate that as the reduction temperature increasing, the coordination unsaturation degree of Zn increases, which could be a strong evidence for the formation of low coordination interface layer induced by the high temperature reduction atmosphere.

To inquire into the electronic structure of the series of catalysts reduced at different temperatures, X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) and X-ray absorption spectrometric (XAS) measurements were performed. As shown in Fig. 4C, the Pt 4f spectra of these four samples deconvoluted with Gaussian peak fitting method are exhibited. For the Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300) sample, the Pt 4f7/2 peak deconvoluted into two peaks at ∼71.38 eV and ∼72.58 eV could be attributed to the Pt° and Pt&+ species, respectively, while the peak at ∼74.68 eV and ∼75.88 eV represent Pt° and Pt&+ species in 4f5/2 regions (Table 2 ) [47]. With the reduction temperature increasing from 300 to 800 °C, the ratio of Pt&+/(Pt°+Pt&+) gradually decreases, and Pt species exhibit an obvious migration to lower binding energy. Peculiarly for the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample, a down-shift of 0.9 eV compared to Pt/ZnTi-MMO(300) is observed. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4D, the normalized X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) curves at the Pt L3-edge exhibited a lower adsorption edge (E0) energy than Pt foil over PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) samples, suggesting the Pt species in PtZn/Zn2TiO4(700) and PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) are electron richness [48]. The above results of XPS and XANES demonstrate that Pt species enriches more electrons with the increasing of reduction temperature, which further confirms that the electronic structure of active metal is strongly related to the interaction with supports.

In addition to Pt 4f, the spectra of Ti 2p, O1 s and Zn LMM were also given to carry out the change in electronic structure of support. As shown in Fig. 5 A, Ti 2p3/2 spectrum deconvoluted into two peaks at ∼458.8 and ∼458.2 eV could be attributed to the Ti3+ and Ti4+ states, respectively [49]. In case of the Zn LMM spectrum (Fig. 5B), two kinetic energy peaks located in ∼988.5 eV and ∼991.5 eV, which could be attributed to the bonding of Zn with lattice O atoms and Zn° species, were exhibited in all samples [18]. When the reduction temperature is 300 °C and 500 °C, the ratio of Zn°/(Zn2++Zn°) did not change significantly; when the reduction temperature increases to 700 °C, the Zn°/(Zn2++Zn°) ratio increases obviously [50]. While an obvious peak between Zn2+ species and Zn° species appears in the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800) sample, indicating that part of Zn exists in the form of Zn&+ species. XPS spectra in the O 1s region for these four samples (Fig. 5C) deconvoluted into three peaks at ∼530.1, ∼531.7 and ∼533.1 eV, which are assigned to the oxide lattice oxygen (Oα), surface-absorbed oxygen species (Oβ) and some weakly adsorbed oxygen species such as surface carbonate and hydroxyl species (Oγ), respectively [51]. To compare the content of oxygen vacancy species over the series of catalysts more appropriately, we calculate the ratio of Oβ to Oα through a deconvolution method of the three peak areas [10]. The ratio of Oβ to Oα among the series samples follows the order Pt/ZnTiO-MMO(300) < Pt/ZnTiO-MMO(500) < PtZn/Zn2TiO4 (700) < PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3(800), which shows that the oxygen vacancy concentration increases gradually with the increase of reduction temperature. Combined with the results from Pt 4f, Zn LMM and Ti 2p spectra that as the reduction temperature increases, as shown in Table S2, the ratio of the Ti3+/(Ti3++Ti4+) and oxygen vacancy concentration enhancing, accompanied by the appearance of Zn&+ species and the decrease of Pt&+/(Pt&++Pt°). Thus, it can be concluded that high temperature reducing atmosphere could significantly promote the interaction between metal and support, inducing the electron transfer from the support to the surface of the metal nanoparticle and leading to the formation of coordination unsaturated ZnTiOx.

Relating the above results, the corresponding structural evolution of the catalyst precursor are thus inferred in Scheme 1 : Under the reducing atmosphere, Pt4+ with the lowest reduction potential in the PtCl6 2-/ZnTi-LDHs precursor is preferentially reduced to form Pt nanoparticles. As the reduction temperature increases, the layer structure of LDHs gradually collapses and converts into mixed metal oxides ZnTi-MMO during the topological transformation, thereby obtaining a catalyst in which monometallic Pt nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the ZnTi-MMO support. When the reduction temperature reaches 500 °C, there is no change in the nanoparticle active components and the crystal structure of the support, while part of the Ti4+ in the support is reduced with a significant increase in oxygen vacancy content. As the temperature goes up to 700 °C, the strong electronic interaction among the formed metal Pt particles and the mixed metal oxides support further promotes part of the Zn2+ to break through the lattice confinement. To be specific, under the induction of a high-temperature reducing atmosphere, the reduction of Zn2+ occurs near the Pt nanoparticles to form highly dispersed PtZn alloys, accompanied by a support transformation from ZnTi-MMO to Zn2TiO4 spinel oxide. When the reduction temperature reaches 800 °C, it could be observed that the support transforms into perovskite-type oxides ZnTiO3. Moreover, the surface support is induced by a high-temperature atmosphere to form a geometric structure of oxide network trap confined metal nanoparticles, and part of the support migrates to the surface of the PtZn alloy nanoparticles to form a low-coordination interface coating layer.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic performance in glycerol selective oxidation
ce:section.ce:para: In order to identify the influence of PtZn alloy and the ZnTiOx interface layer in the process of glycerol oxidation, the mono-metallic Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst and the PtZn/ZnTiO3 alloy catalyst without oxide layers are also prepared. The results of XRD, HAADDF-STEM, CO-FTIR and XPS are used to demonstrate the structure of the mono-metallic and bare PtZn alloys (shown in Figs. S6–10). The corresponding glycerol conversion curves as a function of time are shown in Fig. 6 , which exhibit some discrimination that can not be ignored over the three catalysts. During the whole reaction process, reasonable carbon balance (>90 %) could be observed in all catalysts, only a slight quantity of glycolic acid (GLYCA) caused by CC cleavage. In addition, dihydroxyacetone (DHA), which was the oxidation product of glycerol secondary hydroxyl groups, currently maintains a relatively low selectivity compared to glyceraldehyde (GLYHD) and glyceric acid (GLYA), indicating that all catalysts exhibit a dominant effect on primary hydroxyl groups. It is noteworthy that a large amount of GLYHD are formed during the early stage of glycerol oxidation, which is thought to be the first-step oxidation product. With the increasing of conversion rate, GLYHD is deeply oxidized to GLYA, so that the GLYA selectivity increases, and no obvious discrepancy during the reaction could be observed for all catalysts.

Notably, an obvious distinction of activity could be noticed between mono-metal and PtZn alloy catalysts under identical reaction conditions, while only slight difference between PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 and PtZn/ZnTiO3 was observed. To be specific, when the time reaches 8 h, the conversion of glycerol over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ ZnTiO3(800) and PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalysts reached 80.6 % and 73.0 %, while it is only 57.4 % for Pt/ZnTiO3 (Fig. 6). Furthermore, it is noteworthy that PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst achieves much lower GLYAD selectivity but higher selectivity towards GLYA at the similar conversion than that of PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3, indicating that the low coordination oxide interface has a higher ability to activate the intermediate product glyceraldehyde for further oxidation (Fig. S11). The rapid formation of GLYA over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 shows that it is an effective catalyst for efficiently obtaining GLYA by the promotion of the hydroxyl and aldehyde groups oxidation. Due to the similarity of oxide support crystal structure and metal nanoparticles size, the improvement of glycerol oxidation activity could be attributed to the formation of the PtZn nanoparticles. The interface effect of ZnTiOx layer obviously modifies the geometry and electronic structure of metal, leading to an enhancement of catalytic efficiency to oxidize glyceraldehyde into glyceric acid. Moreover, as shown in Fig. S12, after the used PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst collecting by centrifugation and recycling for 5 times, the conversion (76.2 %) and selectivity (61.3 %) of catalyst only achieve a slight fluctuation compared with that of the fresh catalyst, which could be attributed to the structural stability. To investigate the structural stability of catalyst, the used PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst was characterized by HAADF-STEM, CO-FTIR, XPS and HRTEM analysis. As shown in Figs. S13–S14, the composition and structure of nanoparticles in the used catalyst were exactly similar to the fresh catalyst, indicating that no obvious change of the PtZn alloy structure and metal@oxide interface structure could be observed after reaction. Additionally, a similar particle size of the PtZn alloys in the used catalyst with that of the fresh one (Fig. S15), which clearly proved the strong interaction between PtZn NPs and ZnTiO3 support effectively inhibited the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles during the reaction. Obviously, the in situ LDHs transformation route offers an opportunity to obtain PtZn alloy @ ZnTiOx catalyst with favorable stability. On the basis of the catalytic data, it is worthwhile to pay more attention to the relationship between alloy structure and metal@oxide interface structure on the oxidation performance of glycerol.

To confirm the advantage of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalysts in every single step of the continuous oxidation from multiform perspectives, a series of kinetic experiments by using GLY and GLYHD as reactant are employed. Due to the principle that the related experiments of kinetic study should be in view of rate measurements without the effects of mass or heat transfer, the effect of both the mass of catalysts and stirring speed (600−1000 rpm) on glycerol oxidation were employed over three catalysts. As the mass of catalyst increasing to 134 mg, a linear relation to the glycerol conversion according to the mass is exhibited (Fig. S16), demonstrating that the diffusion limitation is not conspicuous in this range. Additionally, almost no change could be found in the conversion when the stirring speed is changed, manifesting that the reaction space is evenly heated (Fig. S17). Therefore, it may be illustrated that the catalytic performance conditions evaluated in this experiment are in the range where the diffusion limitation is not obvious (1000 rpm, 39.00 mg). Furthermore, the apparent activation energy (Ea) values over the series catalysts are calculated from Arrhenius plots within the kinetic zone (the conversion is lower than 15 %). The apparent activation energy of series catalysts for glycerol oxidation were shown in Fig. 7 D, following the order PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 (25.83 kJ/mol) < PtZn/ZnTiO3 (30.46 kJ/mol) < Pt/ZnTiO3 (40.23 kJ/mol). Notably, the activation energy of glycerol oxidation varies slighter between PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 and PtZn/ZnTiO3 than that between PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3, indicating that the PtZn alloy structure have greater effects on the activation of COH compared with ZnTiOx interface layer structure. Additionally, the Ea for glyceraldehyde oxidation over the series catalysts calculated from Arrhenius plots exhibit apparent gaps with value of 39.69 kJ/mol for PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, 48.87 kJ/mol for PtZn/ZnTiO3, and 52.92 kJ/mol for Pt/ZnTiO3 (shown in Fig. 7, panels E–H). This result is closely corresponding to the catalytic performance in Fig. 6, inferring that low coordination interface structure can effectively reduce the energy barrier of glyceraldehyde oxidation, and has a prominent ability in the further oxidation of aldehyde groups. In summary, PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst has obvious advantages in the conversion process of glycerol to glyceraldehyde and glyceraldehyde to glyceric acid under the synergistic effect of alloy and low coordination interface structure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Activation and mobility behavior of oxygen in glycerol oxidation
ce:section.ce:para: For the oxidation reactions, the activation of oxygen is undoubtedly essential. To further reveal the important role of O2 in glycerol conversion, the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen and the initial reactivity over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts was studied. To be specific, the kinetic study was employed when the initial glycerol concentration remained constant at 0.3 M and the partial pressure of oxygen increased from 0.04 to 0.2 MPa. As shown in Fig. 8 A, the influence of O2 pressures on intrinsic activity of glycerol oxidation could be observed from double logarithmic diagrams of the turnover frequency (TOF) against pO2 with the regression coefficient of R2 > 0.99. Due to the mechanism proposed by Mori et al. and Sadiq et al., the linear correlation can vividly reflect the strong dependence of initial reaction rate of glycerol oxidation on the oxygen activation capacity [52,53]. Therefore, the positive correlation between TOF and partial pressure of oxygen in the series of catalysts indicated that the oxygen activation behavior over the series of Pt-based catalysts has obvious effect on the intrinsic activity of glycerol oxidation.

Aiming to deeply confirm the oxygen activation behavior, O2-TPD was performed to confirm the type and mobility of oxygen species over the three catalysts. The types of desorbed oxygen species on different catalysts can be roughly divided into three types, of which the physically adsorbed oxygen OPhy (<100 °C) and chemically adsorbed oxygen species OChem (200−500 °C) are comparatively facile to desorb, even though the lattice oxygen species OL (>500 °C) is difficult to desorb [54]. Furthermore, the desorption peak near 580 °C can be attributed to the surface lattice oxygen species with coordination unsaturated, while the desorption peak above 650 °C could be allocated to the surface lattice oxygen with saturation [55]. As shown in Fig. 8B, the desorption peaks of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts are indeed different in type and location. The O2-TPD traces of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 and PtZn/ZnTiO3 have two obvious chemically adsorbed peaks near 220 °C and 430 °C, which can be attributed to O2 − and O−, respectively [56]. However, the former one could not be observed over the Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst and the peak position of O− species moves to higher temperature, which indicates a lower activation ability of oxygen. The higher oxygen mobility in PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 and PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalysts can be attributed to the promotion of the oxygen activation over the electron-rich Pt due to PtZn alloying. Moreover, compared with bare PtZn/ZnTiO3, the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst has a lower surface lattice oxygen desorption peak temperature (564 °C), which indicates the increased the mobility of oxygen species.

Combined with the performance difference among the series of catalysts and the widely reported promotion effect of alloy structure on oxygen activity, the contribution of the interface structure to oxygen activation behavior was further explored through O 1s XPS (Fig. S18). The ratio of the peak area (Oβ/Oα) can reflect the relative amount of oxygen vacancies, which are 68.4 % for Pt/ZnTiO3, 70.1 % for PtZn/ZnTiO3 and 95.0 % for PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3. It was generally published that the oxygen vacancies in transition metal oxide catalysts could participate in the process of oxygen storage and migration. Thus, compared with PtZn/ZnTiO3, the enhanced oxygen activation capacity of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 can be ascribed to the obvious increase in oxygen vacancy content. In summary, the above results indicate that the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst has obvious synergistic effect of PtZn alloy and ZnTiOx interface layer with high oxygen vacancy content on the activation of oxygen.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Adsorption and activation behavior of glyceraldehyde in glycerol oxidation reaction
ce:section.ce:para: In situ Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy can effectively obtain the chemical properties and adsorption configurations of the chemical bonds, which is bound to the catalyst surface. The determination of the adsorption modes of glyceraldehyde on the surface of different catalyst is an efficacious method to disclose the controlling factors of selectivity. From the results of catalytic performance, we preliminarily concluded that the existence of low coordination interface can promote the further oxidation of glyceraldehyde, which is closely related to the adsorption behavior of CO bond. Carbon dioxide is a common probe molecule containing two CO bond with linear symmetry, which provides a direct perspective to investigate the adsorption of CO bond by producing various carbonates [57]. Herein, in situ CO2-FTIR is carried out to confirm the influence of different structure on the adsorption of specific molecules [9,58]. Notably, the varieties of carbonates species developed on PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts show a significant difference, involving monodentate carbonate (m−CO3 2−, at 1542, 1465 and 1322 cm−1), bicarbonate (HCO3 −, at 1610 cm−1), carboxylate (CO2 −, at 1654 and 1255 cm−1) and bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2−, at 1565 and 1378 cm−1). To be specific, CO2 − and HCO3 − are generated by CO2 which is absorbed on Ti3+ sites. The m-CO3 2− species are more likely to be exploited on O2− sites, however, b-CO3 2− are preferably generated on low-coordination sites. In the case of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, the intensity of the peaks vested in bidentate carbonate are much stronger than that of monodentate carbonate, indicating that CO2 is mainly absorbed with the type of bidentate carbonate. In addition, the dominant adsorption modes of CO2 in situ CO2-FTIR spectra of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 are different from that of PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts. To be specific, the intensity of the peaks attributed to m-CO3 2− are stronger than that of b-CO3 2−, indicating m-CO3 2− species are dominant in PtZn/ZnTiO3 as well as Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts. It is worth noting that the CO bond in CO2 was destroyed in process of the b-CO3 2− species formation, leading to a stronger CO bond desorption and dissociation ability of the carbonate species adsorbed in the form of bidentate. Compared with PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts, the CO2 adsorbed on the surface of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst is more prone to desorb and dissociate, indicating that the low coordination oxide interface structure can optimize the adsorption method of CO bond.

In the cause of further investigating the different adsorption forms of the CO bond of reaction intermediates during the glycerol oxidation process over different catalysts, the In situ FTIR spectra of catalysts pre-absorbed with glyceraldehyde are employed. Due to the low saturated vapor pressure of glyceraldehyde, it was difficult to directly introduce it into an FTIR system by steam. Therefore, an ex-situ wet impregnation method was used to impregnation the catalysts with glyceraldehyde, and the adsorption behavior of aldehyde group was studied. For PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3, PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts, the In situ FTIR spectra of catalysts pre-absorbed with glyceraldehyde rising slowly among the temperature range of 20–100 °C in a humid O2 atmosphere are shown in Fig. 9 . The regions related to the CH bond and CO/CO bond in 1800−1000 cm−1 indicate the formation of various adsorbed forms of glyceraldehyde species. Regarding to the PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst, the characteristic peaks located at 1062−1, 1126 and 1643 cm−1 are attributed to the glyceraldehyde species adsorbed in molecular form, and the dissociated glyceraldehyde species appear two bidentate adsorbed peaks at 1348 and 1535 cm−1, as well as a monodentate adsorbed peak at 1454 cm−1 [59,60]. Moreover, the amount of bidentate adsorbed glyceraldehyde species is much larger than that of monodentate, illustrating that CO bond of glyceraldehyde species was adsorbed mainly in form of bidentate, which is in accordance with the result of CO2-FTIR (shown in Fig. 9A). In addition, with the temperature reached 40 °C, two new peaks appeared at 1726 and 1238 cm−1, which are attributed to the CO bond and COO− bond stretching vibration in carboxylate, indicating that glyceraldehyde can be easily oxidized to glyceric acid [61]. In the case of PtZn/ZnTiO3 and Pt/ZnTiO3 catalysts, the glyceraldehyde species mainly adsorbed in monodentate form, and the appearance temperature of glyceric acid increased to 80 °C, which illustrate that the bidentate adsorption could promote the rapid conversion of glyceraldehyde to glyceric acid. Based on the above conclusions, due to the CO bond specific adsorption form at the interface of PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst, the aldehyde group has a higher degree of dissociation, which is beneficial to the further oxidation of glyceraldehyde to glyceric acid, thus resulting in a higher glyceric acid selectivity of glycerol oxidation.

In this work, we proposed an approach to construct a novel PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst containing alloy and low-coordination interface structure via moderate reduction of LDH precursors and monitored the in-situ structural topological process. Specifically, PtZn alloy nanoparticles are partially encapsulated by ZnTiOx support, thus forming PtZn@ZnTiOx low-coordinated interface, which was confirmed by HAADF-STEM and EXAFS analysis. To study the structural effect, the PtZn/ZnTiO3 catalyst without ZnTiOx interface layer and monometallic Pt/ZnTiO3 catalyst were also prepared. In selective oxidation of glycerol, the apparent activation energy of the series of catalysts follows the order PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 (25.83 kJ/mol) < PtZn/ZnTiO3 (30.46 kJ/mol) < Pt/ZnTiO3 (40.23 kJ/mol). O2-TPD and XPS confirmed that the enhancement of activity is attributed to the synergistic promotion over oxygen activation behavior by the alloying of PtZn and the abundant oxygen vacancies at the interface layer. In terms of glyceric acid selectivity, the PtZn@ZnTiOx catalyst also possesses non-negligible advantages over both bare PtZn alloy and monometallic Pt catalysts, which was assigned to the low-coordination ZnTiOx at the interface. To be more specific, the In situ FTIR spectra of catalysts pre-absorbed with glyceraldehyde demonstrate that the CO bond in glyceraldehyde molecule is optimally adsorbed on the low coordination interface in the form of bidentate form, which promotes the dissociation degree of glyceraldehyde. Additionally, an excellent reusability with conversion of 76.2 % and selectivity of 61.3 % after 5 cycles was exhibited over PtZn@ZnTiOx/ZnTiO3 catalyst. The findings discussed in this work provide an alternative method to intelligently fabricate stable alloy catalysts modified with low-coordination interface layer, and reveal the synergistic effects of PtZn@ZnTiOx catalyst on the regulation of oxygen activation and intermediate/product adsorption behavior in multistep glycerol oxidation reactions.
